tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship."
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
The heavens are described as if they were a person. AT: "The heavens show" or "The heavens look like they declare"

tn.ref: the skies make his handiwork known
tn.text: The skies are described as if they were a teacher. AT: "The skies seem to make God's handiwork known to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"his creation" or "the world that he has made"

What is beautiful about creation is compared to speaking, as if creation were a person. Then those words are compared to water that flows everywhere. AT: "creation is like a person speaking to everyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: There is no speech or spoken words; their voice is not heard
tn.text: These phrases express clearly that the first two verses were a metaphor. AT: "There is no real speech or spoken words; no one hears an actual voice with their ears"
Other translations read "where their voice is not heard," emphasizing that creation's "speech" is available everywhere.
David has just said that creation shows God's glory.
This refers to the unspoken "words" of creation that show God's glory.
The words are described as if they were people who go out with a message. AT: "the words that creation speaks are like people who go out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: their speech to the end of the world
tn.text: The implied words can be included in the translation. AT: "their speech goes out to the end of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: He has pitched a tent for the sun
tn.text: Here the writer speaks of the place that Yahweh created for the sun as if it were a tent. AT: "He created a place for the sun" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "them" probably refers to the heavens.

tn.ref: The sun is like a bridegroom coming out of his chamber
tn.text: The writer speaks of the sun's coming out as if it were a bridegroom. AT: "The sun is like a bridegroom walking joyfully toward his bride" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: like a strong man who rejoices when he runs his race
tn.text: This compares the sun to an athlete to emphasize the strength and brightness of the sun. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"a fast runner"
the line where the earth and the sky meet
Here "other" refers to the other horizon. This can be stated clearly in the translation. AT: "to the other horizon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "everything feels its heat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: the soul ... the heart ... the eyes
tn.text: All three of these words refer to the whole person. AT: "a person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"those who have no experience" or "those who have not learned"
"are true" or "are correct"
"bringing understanding"
"completely right"

tn.ref: They are of greater value than gold ... they are sweeter than honey
tn.text: Yahweh's decrees are spoken of as if they could be bought and tasted. AT: "If you could buy them, they would be of greater value than gold ... if you could taste them, they would be sweeter than honey" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: even more than much fine gold
tn.text: The implied word "valuable" can be added in the translation. AT: "even more valuable than a lot of fine gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"pure gold" or "expensive gold"
"Also" or "Indeed"

tn.ref: by them your servant is warned
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they warn your servant" or "they are a warning for your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "them" refers to Yahweh's righteous decrees.
David calls himself "your servant" when speaking to God as a sign of respect. AT: "I am warned"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: Who can discern all his own errors?
tn.text: This appears in the form of a question to add emphasis and can be translated as a strong statement. AT: No one can be aware of his own errors!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"from secret mistakes I have made"

This idiom pictures the servant as being removed from the sins he does not wish to commit. AT: "Also, protect your servant from doing" or "Also, make sure that I do not commit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

David calls himself "your servant" when speaking to God as a sign of respect. AT: "I" See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:019:011|19:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: let them not rule over me
tn.text: Sins are described as if they were a king that could rule over someone. AT: "do not let my sins become like a king who rules over me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"innocent of rebelling against you" or "innocent of committing many sins"

tn.ref: the words of my mouth and the thoughts of my heart
tn.text: These expressions taken together describe everything a person says and thinks. AT: "the things I say and the things I think about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"receive approval in your sight" or "be pleasing to you"
This refers to God himself. AT: "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The writer speaks of God as if he were a rock that one could climb and be protected from his enemies. AT: "Yahweh, you are like my rock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
